Journal.Title: Chembiochem : a European journal of chemical biology

Article.ArticleTitle: Phenylalanine Residues Are Very Rapidly Damaged by Nitrate Radicals (NO<sub>3</sub> ⋅) in an Aqueous Environment.

AbstractText: Kinetic studies revealed that nitrate radicals (NO<sub>3</sub> ⋅), which are formed through reaction of the noxious air pollutants nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub> ⋅) and ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ), very rapidly oxidize phenylalanine residues in an aqueous environment, with overall rate coefficients in the 10<sup>8</sup> -10<sup>9</sup>  M<sup>-1</sup>  s<sup>-1</sup> range. With amino acids and dipeptides as model systems, the data suggest that the reaction proceeds via a π-complex between NO<sub>3</sub> ⋅ and the aromatic ring in Phe, which subsequently decays into a charge transfer (CT) complex. The stability of the π-complex is sequence-dependent and is increased when Phe is at the N terminus of the dipeptide. Computations revealed that the considerably more rapid radical-induced oxidation of Phe residues in both neutral and acidic aqueous environments, compared to acetonitrile, can be attributed to stabilization of the CT complex by the protic solvent; this clearly highlights the health-damaging potential of exposure to combined NO<sub>2</sub> ⋅ and O<sub>3</sub> .

It is important to acknowledge that the rate coefficients presented in Table 1, particularly for the dipeptides with Phe residues at the N terminus, should be regarded as the minimum values. The actual rate coefficients for the reaction of NO3⋅ with these substrates at concentrations lower than the start of curvature (i. e., before the kobs plateau) would be higher, but determining them experimentally would prove to be challenging.
Amide neighbouring group effects have been found to facilitate oxidation of the benzylic position in Phe residues:
C. J. Easton, M. C. Merrett, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1996, 118, 3035-3036;
A. K. Croft, C. J. Easton, Austral. J. Chem. 2004, 57, 651-654.
Y. Takano, K. N. Houk, J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2005, 1, 70-77.

The molecular arrangement was determined based on how explicit solvent molecules might interact with the NO3⋅/toluene system. Four solvent molecules were selected to maintain a manageable size of the system, yet still simulate ′solvation′ and enable in the aqueous system hydrogen bonding with NO3⋅ and other H2O molecules, as well as stabilizing developing charges during oxidation of the aromatic ring. By evaluating various arrangements using the CT complex, the calculations indicated that NO3⋅ and two H2O molecules above the plane of the aromatic ring and two H2O molecules below the plane was energetically more favourable than, for example, all four H2O molecules below the plane with only NO3⋅ above the plane. In the calculations of the protonated system, the configuration with H3O+/H2O/NO3⋅ above the plane of the aromatic ring and two H2O below the plane was considerably more favourable than the inverted arrangement with H3O+/H2O, or even all solvent molecules in the opposite side of NO3⋅. In the 4 MeCN system the intermolecular interactions were considerably weaker, resulting in a more flexible arrangement of the solvent molecules across the stationary points.
